Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Radically Efficient Search and Visual Mapping Tool for the Social Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project aims to develop a working prototype for an interactive search and visualization tool that redefines how social scientists and business practitioners interested in scholarly research findings identify such findings. Instead of reading through numerous, unstructured, and often irrelevant text results (such as those produced by traditional academic search engines), users get to (a) instantly view and easily navigate research findings via intuitively-structured, clickable visual maps, and (b) accurately identify those papers most relevant to them, thanks to semantically intelligent indexing and visual reconciliation. This efficiency-enhancing tool makes research findings substantially easier to understand and explore, while drastically cutting down search times for such findings (to half or even less) which will ultimately enhance the efficiency of research endeavors at U.S. universities. Moreover, various inquiries have shown that practitioners in applied fields such as marketing or management place high value on academic research in the social sciences, yet often find such research difficult to understand. The proposed solution distills social science findings into an easily digestible format, hence facilitating the knowledge transfer between academia and businesses, and enhancing the value of academic research to society. Finally, by being marketed as a subscription-based service to both academics and business practitioners, the proposed tool has the potential to generate substantial commercial value in the long term (up to $50 million in annual revenue).

The proposed tool fundamentally alters the existing search paradigm in the social sciences, by changing both the way in which research findings from academic papers are indexed, and how such findings are visually presented. It combines an innovation on the back-end (i.e., using Natural Language Understanding (NLU) to automatically extract concepts and causal relationships from academic research papers, and semantically categorize those concepts against a set of discipline-specific thesauri) with an innovation on the front-end (i.e., using aggregate causal mapping to represent the academic literature in the form of interactive maps that can be visually explored and narrowed down in order to precisely locate relevant papers). The main research objective is to test the feasibility of (1) using NLU for accurately identifying and extracting the underlying concepts/variables and causal structure of the studies described in a large set of social science research papers (approximately 1,000 published papers), and of (2) automatically rendering the extracted information in the form of causal maps that both academic and non-academic users can intuitively understand and navigate. This research objective has been reached if a group of test users employ the proposed tool to successfully identify research papers examining particular concepts and relationships, and do so in about half the time needed when using a traditional academic search engine for the same task.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this Phase I project was to demonstrate the feasibility of building an innovative search and visual mapping tool for the social/behavioral sciences that allows users to search and navigate the academic literature in a highly efficient manner. In conducting this project, we were able to largely meet the technical objectives we had specified in our proposal, and even went beyond their scope in certain cases. Specifically, we accomplished the following:

(1) We manually annotated a set of 200 research papers in consumer psychology, which identified thousands of variables and relationships tested in those papers. These annotated papers served as the training and testing dataset on which we later used a combination of Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning (ML) techniques for variable extraction. To increase the quality and speed of the annotation task, the team ended up developing a custom, web-based document annotation tool for research papers, which can potentially be commercialized as a stand-alone product for researchers, and represents an ancillary outcome of this Phase I project.

(2) Using the set of annotated papers, we applied and tested the accuracy of various NLP and ML approaches for automatically identifying variables (and their causal relationships) from these papers. Our final predictive model produced results that were in line with the technical objectives we had proposed for this grant. We were able to perform variable identification and causal classification with reasonably high accuracy levels (using traditional, per-instance, measures): averages of .79 for precision and between .66 and .8 for recall, between a handful of variable classes. The Hamming Score was determined to be a more appropriate measure of prediction quality for our multi-label, multi-class prediction problem, and our model’s overall Hamming Score was .85. This is generally considered a very good score, but we seek to continue improving the model in the next phase of our project.

(3) We assigned each variable extracted from the annotated set of papers to a full-fledged ontology of consumer psychology concepts, which is integrated with our system’s backend, and currently contains over 3,000 entries for concepts and concept classes.

(4) Harnessing the results of our variable extraction approach, we built a working prototype of our Hyperthesis search and visual mapping tool, which allows users to search the indexed research papers by concepts and causal relationships between concepts, and to visualize and navigate the results via interactive, aggregate causal maps of concepts and relationships. We additionally conducted a user test with 114 social science Ph.D. students to test the effectiveness of this prototype. Consistent with the goal we had specified for this grant, we found that, by using this prototype (versus a more traditional academic search engine like Google Scholar), users can reduce the time needed for identifying research pertaining to a particular causal relationship by at least 40%. This represents a statistically significant drop in search times, whose true, cumulative magnitude is likely to be even larger in the absence of the experimental constraints this test was subject to. The levels of increased efficiency and sheer delight were also evident in users’ comments after the test, which were accompanied by a strong degree of interest in such a tool once it launches.

Overall, the outcomes of our Phase I project demonstrate the feasibility of (1) using Natural Language Understanding (NLP) and Machine Learning (ML) for accurately extracting variables and causal relationships from consumer psychology papers, and (2) rendering the extracted information via an online tool that allows users to (a) get an instantaneous visual overview of the literature in a particular area, and to (b) identify papers investigating causal relationships between concepts significantly faster than when using a traditional academic search engine. We expect that, once fully developed and populated with content from various scientific disciplines, the Hyperthesis tool will radically expedite the way in which faculty and Ph.D. students search for and identify the findings from published research, beginning with social/behavioral science research and potentially expanding into other disciplines that employ experiment-based research, such as the health and life sciences. This will increase the research productivity of scientists, while also helping remove some of the barriers that are currently preventing scientists from undertaking cross-disciplinary research. Moreover, by distilling research findings from academic papers into easy-to-understand visual frameworks, we expect the tool to increase the conceptual accessibility of scientific research to business practitioners, hence facilitating the dissemination of research findings from academia to the industry, and potentially creating new avenues for collaboration between academics and business practitioners. All said, Hyperthesis will ultimately help address two broader societal needs, which the National Research Council (2012) has deemed of vital importance to the nation's prosperity: (a) an increase in research efficiency at American universities, and (b) an enhanced collaboration between academia and the business community.
